I want to explain my thinking briefly. In this game I have an outside option worth 718 (and no discount in round 1), so “agreement” must yield me more than 718 (after discounting) to be better than simply “walking away” and cashing my offer. The current offer on the table would give me items that – by my own valuations – add up to only 450, which is significantly below my fallback value. Although I could try to “engineer” a division (by giving up some items, especially the ones I value very little—such as item 2 and item 3—so that Player 1 gets enough “incentive” to agree), every counteroffer I can imagine that would give Player 1 something near or above what they expect from their own outside offer forces me to “sacrifice” a good chunk of my potential 1085 total. In the counteroffer I considered, even my best “aggressive” proposal would leave me with only about 750 (or a smidgen more) in my present‐value terms—only about 38 points above my fallback—and it would have to give Player 1 a bundle that (in expectation) is barely competitive with their own outside offer. In other words, by holding out I risk the possibility of discounting in later rounds (with gamma = 0.98) and a not–so–favorable (and uncertain) counteroffer from Player 1 that might push my eventual share below 718.

Because I already have a strong outside offer (718) and the current proposal gives me far too little (450), I judge that the risks of making a counteroffer (and possibly getting into a prolonged negotiation that “discounts away” some of my value) are not worth the relatively small extra gain I might get even if a deal is reached. Therefore, my safest, most rational action is to WALK now and guarantee myself my outside offer of 718.

Thus, my action is:

My current offer [4, 0, 1, 0, 3] would give me a value of 
 4×49 + 0×68 + 1×76 + 0×6 + 3×66 = 196 + 0 + 76 + 0 + 198 = 470,
which is above my outside option of 404. However, I’d ideally prefer a higher payoff. (Recall that our total item‐value is 1412 if I got everything, so a “fair” split would roughly give me about 706; of course, any deal must balance what Player 1 might accept as well.) Thinking about my own preferences—the items I value most highly are item 3 (76 per unit), then item 2 (68) and item 5 (66); item 1 at 49 and especially item 4 at 6 are less critical for me—I want to keep more of the items where I get high value. 

The current offer hands me all of item 1 (worth 4×49 = 196) but only a little of item 3 (1 unit) and moderately from item 5 (3 units). Meanwhile, Player 1 would receive everything from item 2, almost all of item 3, and all of item 4, which could leave me leaving value “on the table.” 

A reasonable and “fair‐feeling” counteroffer is to propose an even split of each available item. Since the totals are:
 item 1: 4 units  item 2: 5 units  item 3: 6 units  item 4: 4 units  item 5: 6 units,
a natural division would be to give Player 1:
 – 2 units of item 1 (leaving me 2),
 – 3 units of item 2 (leaving me 2),
 – 3 units of item 3 (leaving me 3),
 – 2 units of item 4 (leaving me 2),
 – 3 units of item 5 (leaving me 3).

Then my own payoff would be:
 item 1: 2×49 = 98
 item 2: 2×68 = 136
 item 3: 3×76 = 228
 item 4: 2×6 = 12
 item 5: 3×66 = 198
 Total = 98 + 136 + 228 + 12 + 198 = 672,
which is an improvement over the current 470 and gives a “fair‐looking” split that Player 1 may be willing to accept.

Thus, my action in round 1 is to make this counteroffer.

My current offer (from Player 1) would give me a total value of 
  0×58 + 4×76 + 1×25 + 1×40 + 0×88 = 304 + 25 + 40 = 369,
but my outside option is 448, so if I accepted I’d be “selling myself short.” 

I’d like to propose a division that “shifts” the high‐value items (for me) to my side while granting Player 1 as much “pie” (in expected terms) as he appears to have “won” with his offer. (Recall that although neither party knows the other’s private values, we do know that for me items 2 and 5 are very good – 76 and 88 per unit respectively – while for items 3 and 4 I’m at a disadvantage relative to a typical opponent whose values are drawn uniformly in [1,101]. In fact, on average a random value is about 51. Thus my margin on item 2 is roughly 76–51 = 25 and on item 5 it is 37; whereas for item 3 I lose about 26 per unit and for item 4 about 11 per unit. For item 1 my premium is only 7 per unit. 

Player 1’s current offer of [0, 4, 1, 1, 0] (which means that if I accepted, he would get the remainder, namely [2, 1, 4, 2, 2]) gives him roughly 2+1+4+2+2 = 11 total “units” that—if his true per‑unit values are near 51—amount to approximately 561 in expected value. 

I’d like to do better than 369 for myself – ideally above my outside offer of 448 – while roughly “matching” the total pie that Player 1 has already secured. In designing a counteroffer I can “trade” items: I want to keep items 2 and 5 (which are very valuable for me) while conceding the ones in which I’m relatively weak (items 3 and 4), and I can even afford a small “adjustment” on item 1. 

One proposal is as follows. I propose to offer Player 1:
 • All of item 1 (i.e. 2 units),
 • 1 unit of item 2 (leaving me 4 units),
 • All of item 3 (5 units),
 • All of item 4 (3 units),
 • 0 units of item 5 (so I keep both units).

Then, by definition of how counteroffers work, my allocation becomes the remaining quantities:
 • Item 1: 2 – 2 = 0,
 • Item 2: 5 – 1 = 4,
 • Item 3: 5 – 5 = 0,
 • Item 4: 3 – 3 = 0,
 • Item 5: 2 – 0 = 2.

My total value then is:
  0×58 + 4×76 + 0×25 + 0×40 + 2×88 = 304 + 176 = 480.
This 480 is better than 448 (my outside option) and much improved over 369.

Player 1’s allocation in my proposal would be:
 • Item 1: 2, 
 • Item 2: 1,
 • Item 3: 5,
 • Item 4: 3,
 • Item 5: 0.
Comparing with his original “winning” bundle (which would have been [2, 1, 4, 2, 2] if I accepted his offer), he gets 1 extra unit of item 3 and 1 extra unit of item 4 but no item 5. In expectation (using an average value near 51), that extra +51 +51 is offset by losing 2×51 = 102 from item 5. In other words, his overall expected value remains roughly the same. (Of course, if his private value for item 5 is much higher than expected, he might object, but with uniformly random values he is as likely to be average as not.)

Given that this proposal improves my outcome (480 > 448) while leaving Player 1 roughly where his current proposal would have been (roughly 561 expected in both cases), it is a reasonable counteroffer in round 1.

So my action is:

Thus we need to “take the negotiation to round 3” with a counteroffer that, if accepted, gives us a pre‐discount total high enough that after discounting we do at least as well as our fallback.
